author: S Harina
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  At the Austin airport, it was presumed by the CLEAR agent that I was not a CLEAR member so when I entered the line, they tried to re-direct me. I stated I had clear, they again re-directed my “all the way down” to a different clear line, maybe? I instead opted for the TSA line which was adjacent to the CLEAR station I was at, however when I entered the TSA line… same clear agent screams “all the way around the corner, that’s not the line, it’s not the line” to which I responded I’m doing TSA pre-check instead so she again ye;;sacross asking “but is that on your boarding pass?”  oblivious that I have TSA pre-check and CLEAR. Furthermore, CLEAR always makes me show my ID despite it advertising as ID-less. All in all, TSA precheck is a more efficient, respectful, organized process. CLEAR is lacking manners.
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Departure Only', 'Date Visit': 'June 2024', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Couple Leisure', 'Queuing Times': 4, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 4, 'Terminal Seating': 3, 'Terminal Signs': 3, 'Food Beverages': 3, 'Airport Shopping': 3, 'Wifi Connectivity': 3, 'Airport Staff': 1, 'Recommended': 'no'}

author: M Hayes
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  I have a been a frequent traveler of Austin-Bergstrom Airport (AUS/KAUS) since the airport opened back in 1999. I have seen the airport grow and change over the years. The changes over the years have been for the better! Notable things about Austin-Bergstrom International (AUS): - there are two terminals the (main) Barbara Jordan terminal where all the restaurants, lounges and stores are, and the South Terminal currently Allegiant and Frontier Airlines. - there is a family viewing area outside the airport for watching planes and having a picnic. There are currently 4 lounges (AA, UA, DL and a Chase Sapphire Terrace) - there are many good places to eat including many local restaurants (my favorite are Taco Deli, Salt Lick BBQ, Second Bar + Kitchen, Annie's, and Juiceland. - it takes about 20 minutes to walk from one end of the terminal to the other, along the way you will see lots of places to eat, drink and shop. Pros: clean, great dining, bars, and rest areas. The Delta lounge is the nicest lounge in the airport. Cons: restaurants close early, so if you arrive on a late(ish) flight you will not have food options.
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Arrival and Departure', 'Date Visit': 'July 2023', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Solo Leisure', 'Queuing Times': 4, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 5, 'Terminal Seating': 4, 'Terminal Signs': 5, 'Food Beverages': 5, 'Airport Shopping': 5, 'Recommended': 'yes'}

author: Anthony Rollett
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Making your customers walk in the searing heat halfway across the airport to find taxis and rides is pathetic. Any chance I get I will tell people what a lousy setup it is. Also there are too few elevators to deal with the people.

author: Prabhat Telidevara
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Getting through security early in the mornings is a nightmare. Very poorly managed. Almost missed my flight. It is necessary to have at least 2 of the 3 checkpoints open any time of the day.

header: "the bathrooms didn’t used to be this dirty"
author: T Kemp
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I’m from Austin, and the bathrooms didn’t used to be this dirty. Since Covid I’ve traveled 10-15 per year, and the bathrooms have consistently been getting dirtier. Even just now, there’s water all over the floor, multiple stalls have no toilet paper, there’s one stall that was too gross to mention, soap and water all over the sinks and mirrors. Please fix this so Austinites can go back to being proud of our airport.

author: C Howard
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Been traveling for a week only have my petty cash left. Get to the airport in Austin Texas expecting to get something to eat and drink for my six year old. Nowhere accepts cash in this  airport except conveniently enough all the bars serving liquor do! Tell me why the staff here find it laughable that I can get a cocktail and pay in cash, but getting a juice is not happening.

author: Penny Ward
reviewBody: Not Verified |  I had ae three hour lay-over and my first time in Austin's airport. From the time I walked into the bathroom, the stench was overwhelming, I actually had to vomit. There was toilet paper all over the floor and body fluids from people utilizing the bathroom on the toilets, floor and especially the most disgusting part tissue holder. I went to find a sandwich to take on my flight and decided to sit at the countertop. The tables were filthy, the trash cans were overflowing. There was no one to ask to assist or call to have someone clean the area. I will avoid at all cost never to go through this airport again. This was and is disgusting.

author: Mari Kostanyan
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Never been so disgusted at customer service before, I am usually not the type to ever write a bad review but everyone I spoke with was rolling eyes and talking with attitude, not to mention there’s no one to help get around considering not everyone knows what exactly to do. dirty bathrooms, extremely crowded and it made me super uncomfortable. I just got off a 4 hour flight, super tired just want to go home, my flight got delayed which isn’t their fault because of the weather but overall so disappointed. This is the first time I have ever been so disappointed in an airport and I have flied many times to many different countries. And we should have higher standards for American airports. How does that happen seriously so disgusting. I have lived here 18 years and have never been more disappointed!

author: Carlise Richmond
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  As a nursing mother the lactation pod as the only option for privacy was absolutely disgusting. Filthy, dirty, dusty, sticky. Wrappers everywhere. Unacceptable to say the least. I used my wipes to try and clean it. And they were almost black. Do better Austin Airport.

author: M Rayne
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  This airport is absolutely disgusting. Trash and food everywhere, packed full of people, rude staff, and limited food options. Not to mention that every time I fly out of here, my flight is delayed. There’s gang stickers all over the place. Just sit down and look around. (If you can even find a seat) The only positive thing I can say is that they offer Disabled Veterans free parking.

author: B Kristen
reviewBody: Not Verified | AUS has limited food options, specifically at breakfast. Those with a 0500 flight time have no real breakfast options. Additionally, I was disappointed the airport didn’t prepare better for holiday travel. Austin has had an influx in its population and the airport already struggles. The holiday travel rush was not well prepared for and the patrons struggled. Open airline check in earlier and security to better serve their customer.

author: Mark Godleski
reviewBody: Not Verified | Austin-Bergstrom International Airport was chaos this morning.  We've already eaten the cost of Delta Airlines tickets, and we're scrambling to get on another airline. There were hundreds of people Outside the doors of the airport at Each security line! It took 2 hours to get through Security this morning. We went to American Airlines where the folks in front of us had missed their flight and they were trying to rebook, and the family behind us had missed their flight and they were trying to rebook. It's 5:45 AM, clear skies, no weather problems. I hope I Never have to use this airport again.

header: "The south terminal was a nightmare getting to/from"
author: Boone Wyatt
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | The south terminal was a nightmare getting to/from. They must have been short handed because the shuttles were about 30 minutes apart and could only hold around 10-15 people at a time. Definitely needs better logistics getting from main terminal to the south terminal.

header: "no place to sit down or eat"
author: Lori Toney
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Terrible experience at this airport! Spent too long waiting for transport to South terminal. Once there no place to sit down or eat! Felt punished for choosing to fly Allegiant!!

author: Daniel Stilwell
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Upon returning my car rental on the 3rd floor of the rental garage, all escalators and elevators were turned off. Since the car was returned there was no way to go down without walking the entire length of the escalator with luggage. Other passengers that were in wheel chairs had children and the elderly could not get down. There were no attendants to assist anyone. This was at 5:30am on a Monday. These should be on 24 hours a day since you can return your car anytime.

header: "no social distancing or hand sanitizers around"
author: Kary Newman
reviewBody: Not Verified |  There was no social distancing or hand sanitizers around, people were just crammed in lines, no one was even worried about it. Every other airport took it seriously and had hand sanitizers everywhere. Austin didn’t seem to take it seriously at all.

header: "seems to continue its decline year after year"
author: Natalie Ciavarella
reviewBody:
Not Verified |  
Austin airport seems to continue its decline year after year. Moving taxis and rideshares to an inconvenient spot that is poorly marked (albeit improved from a few months ago) is compounded by poor shuttle service for those traveling with luggage. The interior is beautiful and I love that they’re bringing in more local businesses, however this could never mask the abysmal experience in trying to leave the airport. The “shuttles” to the taxi stand don’t even assist with luggage anymore. It is such a hassle getting out of this airport I would avoid it at all costs if I didn’t have to go for work.

author: W James
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Simply put, Austin Bergstrom is a surprisingly disappointing airport. Before I venture into the negatives, I do want to highlight the positives of the airport: The terminal opened in 1999, and has largely, recently been renovated. The dining options in the terminal are largely from very local, and locally-themed, restaurants, something unique to airport terminals around the world (as opposed to a local restaurant being located amongst a terminal full of chains). The airport's clean, modern and fairly spacious even given its small size. The seating areas feel more like very nice doctor's offices than the traditional airport seating arrangements. Parking is close to the terminal, even economy parking, and it's reasonably priced. Access off Highway 71 is easy, whether coming from Austin and I-35 to the west or Bastrop and Houston to the southeast. The airport doesn't feel particularly crowded, even during peak passenger traffic hours. And yet, I can't bring myself to give this airport any more than a 4/10 overall rating. I don't particularly enjoy flying out of here. For one, the signs directing drivers to parking areas, arrivals, departures, and the correct lanes for regular vehicles and buses/livery are poorly marked, in my opinion. Even chaotic airports like LAX and O'Hare have better signage for such, strangely. Secondly, once you're within the airport, signage to direct people to check-in areas, rideshare and taxi pickup areas, and security isn't exactly the clearest, not the worst I've seen, but enough to make a small airport relatively confusing. Thirdly, once you're past security, it's surprising to find that the restaurants that serve tacos, meals, margaritas, beers - the things you'd expect to find in an airport in Austin and Texas are slowing down or even closed after 8.00pm. Fourthly, the personnel that work here are very hit and miss, but generally unfriendly. For example, the ticketing agent for Spirit Airlines (not exactly the budget airline with the best reputation) was very pleasant and courteous. The TSA agent who checked my driver's license, a super friendly and chatty guy. But, the shuttle bus drivers between economy parking and the terminal were little more than manner-devoid rubes. The actual x-ray screening agents for TSA were some of the biggest smart-asses (and not the fun kind, but the unpleasant kind) that I've ever met in my life, period. The restaurant servers and bartenders don't give customers eye contact while providing service, and can often be found tapping their feet while interacting with customers and not interacting with one another at all while working. That's the part that leaves me cold; for all the talk of Texas hospitality, it is sparse in this airport. In summary, there are much worse airports in the USA, but there are also much better airports in the USA and abroad. Only fly into Austin if you must!
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Arrival and Departure', 'Date Visit': 'September 2019', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Solo Leisure', 'Queuing Times': 4, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 5, 'Terminal Seating': 5, 'Terminal Signs': 2, 'Food Beverages': 2, 'Airport Shopping': 2, 'Wifi Connectivity': 1, 'Airport Staff': 2, 'Recommended': 'no'}

header: "the best experience we’ve ever had entering the USA"
author: P James
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | This was the best experience we’ve ever had entering the USA. We were literally the first off our plane through an extremely quiet immigration area and greeted by the most pleasant Customs Officer ever. He was so charming and full of local advice and obviously very proud of his city. He even searched for events for us to go to and could not have been more helpful. It is a quieter airport compared to somewhere like Miami so maybe they are more laid back but the difference it made to the start of our holiday was amazing. Well done Austin.
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Arrival Only', 'Date Visit': 'September 2019', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Couple Leisure', 'Queuing Times': 5, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 4, 'Terminal Signs': 4, 'Food Beverages': 0, 'Airport Staff': 5, 'Recommended': 'yes'}

author: Jeff Adams
reviewBody: Not Verified |  None of the vendors take cash. None of the food service people understand that folks have flights to catch. Slow as molasses like they could not care less with 5 others in the back. Very unprofessional. Where is the Starbucks? I’ve tried all the coffee places with the many trips I have taken and none come close. I just want a large, (big) iced coffee when I get off the plane like any other airport. Of the many airports I travel through, Austin gets the worst rating.
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Arrival and Departure', 'Date Visit': 'September 2019', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Business', 'Queuing Times': 1, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 3, 'Terminal Seating': 3, 'Terminal Signs': 1, 'Food Beverages': 1, 'Airport Shopping': 2, 'Wifi Connectivity': 3, 'Airport Staff': 4, 'Recommended': 'no'}

author: E Clay
reviewBody: Not Verified | Austin International Airport fail. Waited 30 minutes to open the airplane doors. 10 electronic passport control machines for nearly 500 passengers. 8 work. Had to stand in line to recheck our bags to our final destination behind all the people that were originating in Austin (we had just flown 11 hrs in from Lisbon.) Other airports do a simple recheck right after customs. TSA very rude and inefficient. I’ve never had to separate carryon snacks for the X-ray at any other airport. Of course our bags didn’t make it and the airline won’t deliver them since the recheck made them categorized as late. Alaska personnel were fantastic but I will avoid Austin at all costs from now on.

header: "very hard to see in the dark"
author: J Masters
reviewBody: ❌ Not Verified |  The parking garage also houses the rental car companies. The garage is under construction and the signage for Rental Car Return is so dusty it is very hard to see in the dark (5.45 am on May 19, 2018). I missed it twice and had to ask airport security where it was. It took 30 minutes to find it, causing me to miss my flight. (Also, on entering the terminal there is no signage showing which airlines are to the left and to the right.) Fortunately my airline re-booked me on the afternoon flight at no extra charge. The chances are very low that I will never use this airport again.

header: "Hard to find where you need to go"
author: M Simpson
reviewBody: ❌ Not Verified |  Shuttles to and from parking areas and south terminal involve a long wait in the heat and a rather long ride. Shuttle drivers are courteous. Hard to find where you need to go because directions are not clearly posted. All in all rather inconvenient. Maybe it will be better when construction is complete.

author: Al Creech
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  I have traveled all over the world and have used some digusting mens rooms. Today, I felt like I entered a 3rd world men's room this morning. Had to clean my own toilet seat. My wife used the ladies room the same time. She was surprised how filthy it was. Someone should lose their job.

author: Carter Welch
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Austin-Bergstrom is a pleasant airport. The lines at TSA were very mild while we were at this airport, and the design of the airport is open and clean. Check-in with Southwest was as easy as usual, staff were friendly. The seating at the gates was plentiful, something which is surprisingly uncommon across the US. However, food and shopping options seemed severely limited and the airport was undergoing construction.

author: R Andrews
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Long delays due to technical difficulties at the airport. On my original day of departure, the Austin computers were down and the flight was expected to be delayed by 45 mins due to manual checking process. Since I was going to miss my Atlanta connection, I rebooked my flight for the next morning and stayed an extra night in Austin. The next morning the jetway was broken at my gate and the flight was delayed yet again for more than 45 mins. Both times, it seemed to take much longer than necessary to adjust to or fix these problems which is just unaccectable. Austin airport is currently not able to adapt to the increased traffic of this city.

author: S Saunders
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  This is the worst airport ever. As a business traveler and having just moved to Austin this year from Dallas, TX I never realized how spoiled I was living in Dallas and traveling from DFW. The city of Austin is in denial. This airport is so busy and doesn’t even have enough gates, not many direct flights, no services. Security lines horrible, traffic at drop off and pick up is a nightmare. With all the people moving in to Austin you would think that the city would expand the airport, expand highways and improve infrastructure. Unfortunately this city lacks major infrastructure. If you are thinking about moving to Austin think again. I am moving back due to this airport. This year has been nothing but living hell traveling weekly through this airport.

header: "badly in need of expansion and modernization"
author: D Williams
reviewBody: Worst airport in USA. Outdated, poor set up, and not nearly enough seating. Very bad TSA security set up leads to long lines. For sure the worst food selections at typical rip off prices. On site parking is a joke if you have to take a bus to your car, either several buses when you don't need them or long lines when you do. Like the city of Austin and entire Austin area, this too has been mismanaged for years by clueless mayors and city councils. This airport is badly in need of expansion and modernization, and new management. Not a very good travel experience.

author: George Skelton
reviewBody: Austin is one of my least favorite airports in Texas. Long security lines. Limited seating at gates. No plugs to charge phones. But there are good barbecues and music if you have time to enjoy. The rental car facility is half way to Dallas. Rates are high. Cheaper to Uber than rent a car. Construction on highway at entrance to airport slows you down. Signage to rent a car area is poor and causes confusion. Best tip is to go through west side security. This is a perfect airport for Southwest flyers who want that cattle car experience like Love Field.
stats: {'Experience At Airport': 'Arrival and Departure', 'Date Visit': 'February 2016', 'Type Of Traveller': 'Business', 'Queuing Times': 3, 'Terminal Cleanliness': 2, 'Terminal Seating': 1, 'Terminal Signs': 2, 'Food Beverages': 4, 'Airport Shopping': 2, 'Wifi Connectivity': 3, 'Airport Staff': 2, 'Recommended': 'no'}

author: Aaron Burkart
reviewBody: Flew in from Las Vegas to Austin-Bergstrom via Frontier Airlines with my fiancee. I had done my research on the airport and knew it was not like the other airports I'd experienced before (Vegas, LAX, Phoenix and JFK were all far bigger, and Kahului was much smaller). When we landed, other than an adventure to find the rental car facility (which is hidden above a parking garage across from the terminal, just in case you're headed that way soon), our process was very smooth. All we had was a carry-on, so no hassles with checked baggage. Everything in the airport was pretty clear, though I would hope they'd make some updates soon, as the city seems to be outgrowing this airport already. ABIA is smaller than almost any other big-city airport, but the layout is easy to follow for the most part. Checking back in for departure was something of a difficulty (but being a Sunday night, I expected no different). TSA was helpful, but lines were not clearly defined. Check-in kiosks for Frontier were hidden, but easy to use once we found them. Overall great experience, but this place needs to grow a bit more to fit its city.

author: Amod Daherkar
reviewBody: I found Austin Airport to be clean and fresh, however it did have crowded immigration and was rather small, other than that great.

author: E Englert
reviewBody: A lot of reviews for Austin—Bergstrom International Airport are outdated (it's been a long time since 2009 y'all) or simply have nothing to do with the airport, such as hotel shuttles or traffic. I will admit a bit of bias on my part since this is my hometown, but really it's one of the best mid-size airports in the country. Terminal Signs and Directions: the airport installed interactive screens that help with way-finding. They are useable, but kind of slow. Signage is abundant throughout the main terminal. Queueing Times: In July 2015, ABIA expanded its ability to handle passengers significantly with the opening of a new passenger screening and customs facility. It's significantly easier to access the eastern part of the terminal from check-in. Terminal Cleanliness: The terminal is kept rather clean, and recycling stations are abundant throughout the terminal. The sorted system is somewhat unnecessary given the city's switch in recycling policy, but they're well-used. Terminal Facilities: There's some funky art in the terminal, and not in a good way. That being said, the airport is a sleek, modern building that can be somewhat overtaxed at times, especially around festivals, but befitting of the city. The Admirals Club leaves something to be desired. Not enough outlets. Food and Beverages: Good to excellent. Mostly local companies. The reason I take off a star is because honestly sometimes I just want some disgusting, processed fast food, and ABIA doesn't really have that. Airport Shopping: Again, mostly local companies operating stores, which limits the selection to Austin-themed merchandise, with no real duty-free. It's nice but nothing remarkable. Airport WiFi Service: Okay this is probably my biggest sticking point. The city is a high-tech hub. We're world-renowned for our technology sector. The WiFi should not be limited to "Free for 30 minutes". The airport has been growing for about five years straight as of writing this review, with several record-breaking years in a row. There's always something new to check out, whether it's an art exhibit or a new destination or airline being added. We've had two international carriers come in and start highly successful routes in as many years. I'm hoping the airport can keep up with the momentum.

author: John Walker
reviewBody: I had several trips each quarter to AUS giving me a chance to figure out how to use the airport. First give yourself lots of time to get from your starting point to the airport by car as the roads in and around Austin are terrible - badly designed and poorly maintained with tremendous volumes of traffic. Second give yourself more time if you are on the first flights of the day as the check-in and TSA security cannot handle the large volumes first thing in the day. Third prepare to have some sort of strange interaction with the TSA as they exercise their improbable variant of "logic". Fourth eat before you go to the airport as the options inside the "secure" area are plentiful but of poor quality. Otherwise once you are inside the "sterile" area the airport is well-designed and I see others have mentioned the good massage spot near gate 13. The bathrooms are excellent. Unfortunately you frequently need something like a stiff drink and a massage to release the tension associated with the bad roads long lines and ridiculous TSA.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: E Mabley
reviewBody: Austin Bergstrom Int'l is one of the best American regional airports. Southwest and American dominate here it can be costly to fly to/from the US west and east coasts and international service is non existent but the airport is among the most well-designed and efficient. The terminal is spacious overcrowding is seldom an issue and there are plenty of dining and shopping options. This airport should be used as a model for all new medium-size airports being planned.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: John Philipps
reviewBody: One key to a good trip through AUS is to minimize your time within the sterile area as the activities are very limited. The restaurants within security are relatively expensive and serve very poor food especially those that purport to be airport versions of the local fare. No Starbucks. If you can avoid evening departures as this is when the live musicians play in the center area causing an already noisy airport ambience to become even worse. If you can avoid early morning flights as the TSA security theater is made worse by inadequate entrances resulting in lines that stretch the length of the terminal. For those with checked in luggage the lengthy wait times upon arrival can be problematic; however the airport restrooms are some of the best in the US. AUS has both a good heel bar and an excellent massage kiosk. The roads to the airport are very very poor and the signs are confusing at best just like the rest of the city so plan lots of extra time to get to the airport on the terrible Austin roads. The car rental facility is on site although "customer service" can be a problem.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: J Levitsky
reviewBody: The roads around the airport are poorly designed and constructed so it is not easy to find the airport or the rental car facility. This is also true of the rest of the Austin region so this is not unusual for the city where correct signage is at a premium. No Starbucks but lots of other local restaurants although their menus are limited. Lots of light and high ceilings but not an airport to spend lots of time at unless you like the massage spot.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: Bruce Roberson
reviewBody: Austin has free internet service Downtown but not at their airport. There is Not a Starbucks but they have a local substitute of a high blend coffee shop. I feel sorry for families traveling because there is not any kind of restaurant food that children will recognize. It would be nice too if there were more electrical outlets for laptops and phone chargers. It is kept very clean and the easy access to rental cars is a very big plus! Amy's Icecream is worth the calories.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: R Jones
reviewBody: AUS is decidedly different from a lot of airports in that it tries to be well Austin. There's a live music stage in the center of the terminal and local businesses dominate the shopping scene. Much of that as other posters noted is annoying as you can't get a cheap snack and lines can be long. Shops are definitely "Austin" but needlessly expensive. The music is well hit and miss. I prefer quiet to some of that stuff! For the Starbuck's fans there's one in the terminal now. There are "Austin-inspired" murals above check-in. Great to have local artists but the art is rather pedestrian showing scenes of poor Hispanics. I think there's probably more to Austin than that. Getting in and out is easy although I have had long luggage waits. The roads and signage to the airport are OK but getting better. Seems like they built this airport without figuring out how to get to/from the place. No freeways to the place but supposedly they're working on it. Parking is not cheap but not expensive either by some standards. The cheapest is $7/day. Better to take the bus if you can if going away a long time. Car rental is usually easy. Taxi is easy. Blue Van may be a long wait and long drive as they drop off others. Early am flights (6:30am and earlier) are insane. Long long lines at security as all airlines seem to have flights at this time. Arriving earlier is not an option as the airline check-in counters and security don't open until around 5:30am.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}

author: G Kohl
reviewBody: Austin airport is fine as long as you do not have to wait very long for your flight. Two good parts of the airport are the well-lit spacious feel to the building and the little masseuse station near gate 13. Otherwise the dining opportunities are very weak. If you want a Starbucks for instance forget it. If you want pale imitations of local restaurant chains you are in luck. Even more useless is an entire store a large store devoted to a local college football team souvenirs. The roads to the airport are terrible. Poorly-designed traffic flow is compounded by missing or misleading signage so visitors in rental cars give yourself plenty of time to find the airport and return your car. Customer service at the airport is not very good although not as bad as LAX or PHL obviously.
stats: {'Recommended': 'no'}
